Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Linear Algebra
basic linear algebra. Did not really talk about concrete applications but one could imagine the usefulness of the material.
Learned linear algregra
Matrix algebra, vector subspaces, projections, orthogonality, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, several forms of matrix decomposition, and positive definites.
I learned about theories and mathematical concepts relating to linear algebra.
matrices, matrix operations, transformations, and much more!

We learned about matrices I guess. I was a little disappointed in the "applications" presented in the course. I expected them to seem more relevant and urgent, given how important linear is to just about anything quantitative (esp. data science stuff). I didn't feel like these applications were presented to us in concrete terms.
A good summary of the core topics in linear algebra.

In addition to the math, this course, more than most I've taken, taught me the importance of studying, and mastering the material. It's very straightforward if you get it, and very abstruse if you're not prepared. I had to accept and come back from my first ever test failure in this course.
I learned linear algebra and the necessity of effectively using my time.
Developed knowledge of linear algebra skills, including vector spaces, orthogonality, determinants, and eigenvectors.
This class was a clear introduction to the main computational concepts in Linear Algebra.

As a poli sci major, I found this class surprisingly accessible thanks to Prof Uyanik's teaching style. This is essentially a class about matrices and its applications. Important if you have any interest in data.

I refined technical calculation skills (i.e. agility when it comes to solving equations quickly), since much of the work we did with matrices involved basic mathematical operations. I also learned new ways to apply core principles of linear algebra, such as diagonalization of matrices being applied to fast computing. This class improved my spatial understanding of math since students were always encouraged to consider geometric implications of problems (in addition to algebraic formats).

Linear Algebra 
(1) Matrices and Gaussian elimination
(2) Vector Spaces
(3) Orthogonality
(4) Determinants
(5) Eigenvalues and eigenvectors
(6) Positive definite matrices
You learn linear algebra as the name of the course suggests: matrix multiplication, inverses, vector spaces, orthogonality, eigenvalues/eigenvectors, etc.
Learned a bunch about linear algebra obviously and it was great to see how it forms the basis of pretty much all mathematics.
A good foundation in basic linear algebra - matrices, vector spaces/subspaces, linear transformations, determinants, and eigenvalues/eigenvectors.
You get a thorough overview of linear algebra from an applications, not proof based, point of view.
I learned about the characteristics of matrices and their many applications for solving problems in mathematics.
I learned how much I love math.
I learned about linear algebra and some applications. Mostly, I learned about how matrices work and how to compute things using matrices.
I learned the basic properties and mathematical manipulations of matrices.

The course achieves exactly what it sets out to do - you learn the basics of linear algebra and how to apply them. At the end of the course you emerge comfortable with the material and how to use it. Definitely not one of these course the material of which I forget the minute I leave the exam room.
Honestly little. Random facts or theorems, but I had learned most material in other classes and I found the random tidbits to confuse the larger ideas.
I learnt linear algebra
Linear Algebra!!!

Math222 provided a foundational introduction to linear algebra with occasional relevant applications. The name is a bit misleading as most of the course is spent reviewing fundamental theorems of linear algebra and applications are interspersed (volume by determinants, finding inverses, matrix computation). Math222 taught me the basis of linear algebra necessary for upper-level classes in graph theory, computer science, etc.
Very basic computational insights on linear algebra
linear algebra

Higher Dimensional Mathematics! Matrix Operations, Vector Spaces, Subspaces, Linear Transformations, Orthogonal Matrices and Subspaces, Projections, Determinants, Eigenvectors/values, interesting matrix decompositions, positive definite matrices, single value decomposition
I learnt linear algebra concepts.
Linear algebra: solving systems of equations, subspaces, orthogonality, etc
I learned the fundamental concepts of linear algebra, and drew connections between it and statistical and programming techniques I had been using for years.
I learned a lot about linear algebra computations and applications.

Prof Uganik is absolutely fantastic. Though, instead on spending the last week reviewing content we could have learned more--I wish we covered the entire book (all the eight chapters) rather than just 6. We also skipped over some material (least squares) that I wish we would have learned in class.

This course required a lot of time, but not much effort. In particular, aside from the three classes, there were also two (highly recommended) discussion sections, which adds up to a total of 5 meetings per week. That being said, the material was taught in such a clear and nicely-paced manner such that it was not completely necessary to attend the sections. 

It could be improved by providing more concrete application examples of the material. We skipped the most applicable section of the least-squares.

There could also have been greater communication between the TA and professor in terms of material covered in section.

Strengths
Lectures were always clear and concise. Caglar is an exceptional lecturer.

Weaknesses
Pacing and workload were suboptimal at the start of the semester, but this was improved after student feedback
Homework solutions were not posted consistently

The course follows a very didactic sequence, and the material is not too complex. However, although it is called Linear Algebra with Applications, we didn't quite cover any applications. I would see this course as an easier version of 225, since proofs are not required.
The class work is demanding and sometimes feels like busy work. On the other hand, the professor gives good lectures and wants his students to succeed.
Very well organised and well paced -- psets and exams are fair and helpful. The book is enough to understand the information and the lectures are helpful as well!

Strength: Caglar really cares about his students, and is a methodical lecturer. He is a good teacher and takes questions openly. 
Weaknesses: The textbook is pretty frustrating. It isn't set up like most math textbooks. Some problems take forever, some don't seem to have a question in them. The applications of linear were not presented clearly.

Caglar was a great lecturer and that was the greatest strength of the course. However, I didn't find the textbook very clear or helpful and I hope that future professors of MATH 222 find a better linear algebra text. I would also hope to see more applications of the material taught in the future.
I think the pace of the class was very good. More clarity on what is actually covered in class concerning the assigned textbook chapters would be helpful, as Strang had some extraneous information.

A lot of people are wishing that this course had more tie-in with multivariable calculus and differential equations. Perhaps Yale should take a page from other schools, and teach multivariable and linear as a single, integrated course, and have a continuous curriculum into differential equations.
I also signed up for this course because it would have applications instead of proofs, unlike MATH 225, but instead, we were still taught proofs. The only thing was, we weren't required to know them. So a lot of time, in my opinion, was wasted.
It was honestly a great course, I just didn't apply myself well enough. I think this course would have been better as a seminar, to improve student engagement.
The major strength of this course was the professor. He knew how to teach the subject matter well.

Strong -- very clear lectures, excellent board management 
Weak -- problem sets can be long (to be expected though)

Strengths: A manageable workload, and professor Uyanik is quite warm to students. 

Weakness: The TF-led section were scheduled at times that were not very accessible to a lot of people. If you take this class in a 5-credit semester, be prepared to grind.

The course could have been better organized in terms of feedback. This was no fault of the professor, but the graders who failed to return corrected problem sets promptly hindered my ability to study properly for some exams. In addition, peer tutor hours on Sunday were useful since homework was due on Monday but the other peer tutor hours took place too early in the week for that session to be useful.

1. Professor is very clear when teaching - it is easy to follow the material and read the textbook to learn if need be. 
2. Weakness - p-sets at the beginning of the semester were unnecessarily long and tedious
Overall, I don't have qualms with this course. It was very strong and I don't know how I would improve it.

Strengths: this year the class is taught by Caglar Uyanik and he is the greatest strength of this class imo. He is a really chill person and explains the material really well. The exams are very fair and test what Caglar tells you will be tested. 
Weaknesses: the computational aspect of this class can be reduced a little bit and replaced with more conceptual stuff (I really wish Caglar had given more focus on proofs, because spending 20 minutes calculating the inverse of some ridiculous matrix or the determinant of a 4*4 matrix is just too boring compared to doing a conceptual proof). The class does require conceptual understanding though so don't think that simply knowing how to calculate things will make you do well (there are True/False questions on the exams that are like mini-proof/conceptual questions).
Additional weakness: apparently each time this class is taught by a different person so what I wrote down here might not apply to whatever version of MATH 222 that you will be taking. Do look up the instructor for your semester (I've heard from a friend in my class that the last time she took 222 she dropped it because the instructor was pretty hard and gave ridiculous exams that resembled nothing in the homework sets).
I believe the course could be taught in a better order.  Personally I would prefer the graphical approach to linear algebra rather than the algebraic.

Course was great and well structured, only weakness was that the graders didn't grade our last three homeworks, and that is no fault of the professor. He made numerous attempts to contact the graders and the Mathematics DUS as well but they either refused to do anything or ghosted him. Really unprofessional on the Math department's side.

Overall, this was one of my favorite classes the past semester. Well-structured, the professor clearly cared about the students, and content was conveyed effectively through very clean lectures that made sense. Caglar is a great professor. The only thing I might have liked more would have been to explore some of the proofs and logic more as a class--but that is difficult to do with a lecture.
The main strength of the course in the professor! He was super understanding of students and always available to help out.
It wasnt incredibly application based until the end

I think lectures are very informative and for the most part taught us everything we needed to know for homework and exams. The material that was covered was distinctly what was on our exams which was very fair. There was also a logical organization of the course in regards to how we worked through each chapter. There was also plenty of opportunities to clarify information in the course by attending office hours, discussion sections, and by speaking with the professor before or after class. This class could be improved by helping clarify answers to homework questions because their current solutions that were provided were brief and didn't offer much of an explanation.
Great explanations and good practices in lecture. But sometimes felt a bit discontinuous between sections.

Strengths: if caglar is teaching this, TAKE THIS IMMEDIATELY EVEN IF YOU DON'T NEED TO. BEST CLASS EVER

Weaknesses: i can't think of any
strengths were that is was pretty straight forward material and the lecture was easy to follow/understand.

the strengths are that the material in itself is not extremely conceptually difficult, and it is very interesting. The math is pretty intuitive and feels profound. The class also builds neatly upon itself.

Overall it was a very well taught course - everything you need to know is covered well in lecture and the psets help solidify the applications. At the beginning of the course, however, Caglar was a little unclear (when talking about the 4 fundamental subspaces), often going over the same thing multiple times but in different ways. Perhaps that could be due to the fact thats its his first time teaching this course. Afterwards, that improved however. If you ever feel lost, I would recommend looking up MIT linear algebra notes online - theyre very useful.

The course was extremely well-taught. It was very well organized in a way that facilitated learning. It covered a few topics on linear algebra, so it was not overwhelming. I really enjoyed that the lectures were handwritten and were not seen through projector slides. It kept the pace of the course consistent and slow and we were always sure that we would never miss something. It was also a very good motivation for attending lectures.
Change textbooks. It is a terribly written and organized book. Get to determinats sooner. It's weird to keep them at the end.

The class seemed to go smoother than what had been forewarned by previous takers. Assessments were fair, and homework assignments were not terribly long. Your performance in the class is purely a reflection of how well you know the math.
I wish psets were more of grade because they were long

Strengths: Professor Caglar Uyanik was an amazing teacher. He put so much time into explaining the topics, holding review sessions and answering questions during office hours. 

Weaknesses: This is an application based class. Proofs could make it better, but because of the nature of the Math 222, there is not much proofs in the class.

The course covers relevant topics with plenty of examples and online resources. That said, the textbook feels very dated, and often times important concepts are hidden from the chapter reading only to be discovered in the actual problem sets (ex: relevant theorems are often stated in the problem sets). The greatest strength of this course is that, when taught with an excellent instructor like Professor Uyanik, the material is clearly presented, easy to understand, and accessible. Unlike other math classes, the material does not feel intangible.
Very orderly and coherent, computationally heavy. Does not go in depth. Perhaps that is how the class was made to be.

The beginning of the course was very bad. I did not feel that Professor Uyanik prepared me well for the first midterm exam, I had to teach myself everything through YouTube and reading the textbook. The second 2 sections of the course got better, but that's largely because I realized I just had to teach myself a lot of the material and the material builds heavily upon itself, so it forces you to figure out what is happening.
Amazing class, could be improved by going faster to cover more material.
Quizes would be better instead of homeworks. For midterms 50 minutes is not enough.

The class can be frustrating, not due to the class structure, but rather just by the fact that there is such a variety of students with different backgrounds. Some people know more than others. But if you take advantage of all the resources (professor, TA, etc), there are ways to succeed. The topics are interesting, though I don't feel like there were many "applications" and the content was sometimes more theoretical than I anticipated.

Strengths: Clarity of presentation of material and expectations for homework and exams. Flexible office hours from tutors, the TA, and the professor himself, such that almost any schedule could be accommodated.

Weaknesses: Would have liked to see more coverage of Least Squares, an applied concept important in Economics and many other disciplines. While we learned concepts relevant to this technique, covering actual problems would have been appreciated.

Caglar was an excellent professor, with clear, straightforward lectures, and I definitely felt like I learned a lot. I do think focusing more on the applications of linear algebra could have been helpful, but I understand that there was not much time for this.

I enjoyed the format of the course, but I think it may benefit from a structure like Math 120, where there are several smaller sections. However, you would need to ensure that you have the adequate amount of teaching staff to teach the course well.

I Cr/D/F'd this course, but I really did enjoy it! I thought that overall, it was very engaging. While overall lectures tend to bore me, Prof Uyanik is amazing and I rarely scrolled through my phone/repeatedly checked the time.
Yes, one hundred percent only if Caglar is teaching it. He's a phenomenal teacher. He really makes sure that each student understands the material before moving on to the next topic.
Yes. It's a good math class and all the topics are relatively easy to understand.
Yes. I gained very useful knowledge from this course, especially regarding methods to solve systems of equations.

The class with Professor Uyanik was the best version of this course I've shopped/attended/taken in part. Highly recommend any course with him -- he tests what he teaches and teaches it well. The course is well structured and easy to follow -- one of the most well taught math classes at Yale, where the pace and content maximised my learning. I didn't spend most of my time trying to reteach myself the material, but could spend most of my time practicing using the material. The information is also useful to Computer Science and Physics, for example.

I would only recommend this class to you if you have a clear reason for taking it. This doesn't have to be that it is a requirement for your major. It could be that you like data science and want to get to know it a bit better. That said, I am not someone who needed to take this class, and I did not get as much from it as I'd hoped. I can do some matrix manipulation, but I am missing the bigger picture -- the applications.

Linear algebra is a good foundation for all quantitative fields and you will get a decent sense of lin alg by the end of this course. However, we didn't really learn any applications in math 222 which was pretty disappointing. And the textbook wasn't helpful. But Caglar is math 222's saving grace

Yes Dr. Uyanik genuinely cares about his students and is a nice person that is patient and willing to clear about any confusion we had about the course materials. He is an angel compared to the 241 teacher.
Yes, it is a really cool and important subject and the class is very well organized.
I mean, take it if it's required, I guess. Probably better than taking 225 if you're like me and don't really want to take math.
Yes, I think this is the more useful of the linear algebra courses. Though 230 might have more interesting topics, 222 is really the most useful.
I would highly recommend this course to another student if Caglar Uyanik is teaching it. He made hard concepts very easy to understand.
Yes

I would definitely recommend this course to any student so long as Caglar Uyanik is teaching. He genuinely cares for students and tends to have a fair attitude. Be warned that the subject matter can be a bit dense at first, but if you hang in there it can be rather satisfying to see how all the concepts interact (that's coming from a humanities major). The midterms are fair enough, but be warned that their shorter length means a few small mistakes can have a big effect on your overall grade.

Yes, it's a great course if you want to hone algebra skills and learn more about applications of matrices. The workload is very manageable, tests are straightforward (calculation-based so if you know how to do the problems on the homework, that knowledge will translate on the tests).
Yes - if you need it, sure. It is useful to learn linear algebra because it can me be applied to many other stem/physics/mech.etc. class types.
Yes. I really enjoyed this course and I'm very confident that I mastered the skills taught in this class that will help for future courses.
Yes, depending on who teaches it. Caglar is pretty good so if he teaches this class again I recommend you take it. However, I can't speak for other professors.
Yes, this is such a great course and though it seems daunting, Prof. Uyanik explains things so well.

I'd highly recommend this class if it's taught by Caglar again! Usually math classes feel like rote memorizing formulas from the textbook but this class truly pushed me to think logically in different ways. It was so satisfying at the end of the semester to be able to cross-apply or derive the logic behind solving different problems. Caglar is an incredible, caring, funny professor who was welcoming during office hours and great at explaining the course material.
I would recommend it to any student who wants to continue their mathematical studies. It's useful and much more practical, in my opinion, than a proof based course.

I would recommend this course to another student because I think it is organized very well to succeed in. Not much previous mathematical knowledge is required to participate as we mostly worked with matrices and their many applications. The class had problem sets each week that weren't too long, and students had plenty of opportunities to get help. Exams were also very fair and based on problems strictly in our homework. The professor says that as long as we studied our notes and our problem set then we would do well in his class and he was correct. Overall, the content of the course was relatively interesting.
I would only recommend if necessary for major - difficult concepts and doesnt seem much use. Often seems we were doing math just for maths sake.
YES. This built my foundation so well in terms of mathematics.

It is tough, and relatively pointless considering everything learned can be done with a computer, but I figure if you enjoy putting in extra work (or just have to get er done for your major) go for it
Yes, if you want to learn a useful math skill.

Yes! I think that the class this semester was better than it has ever been (or at least in recent years). I used to hear horror stories about this class from friends, but it was not that bad. I don't think this is because of my own abilities, but rather to differences in the professors we had. They should take this course if they can take it with Caglar. That is all I can say.
I would recommend this course only if it is taught again by Professor Uyanik. The math department is infamous for having atrocious professors and he was a very bright exception.

Even if you're not an engineering or math major, if you have any interest or feel it might be useful to learn linear algebra, I would recommend taking the course, and potentially Cr/D if you don't want to take a hit to the GPA.
Yes, definitely!

I would highly recommend this course to another student if Professor Uyanik is teaching. This math class does not suffer from the same issues that plague math112/115/120 and provides an essential foundation for mathematical maturity in relevant fields of application. Also, it's a major requirement for many STEM students and is a painless version of 225.
Easy fifth if you decent at math with Caglar

Yes but beware. Looking back, I do enjoy the material but I had to teach myself leading up to the midterms. The beginning 1/3 with professor Uyanik will be rough but once you understand the foundation the course builds upon itself so much you will be fine.
YES!!!!!!!! No doubt about it. This is one of the best math classes I've taken at Yale and is taught by an amazing professor! You'll be inspired to take more math classes after this!
I recommend

Most people take this as a requirement, so you probably have to take it. It's a lot of work--psets take a while and the best way to study is to do tons of practice problems. Go to section and office hours and find people to work with. Prof. Uyanik is a clear and fair professor and his exams are also fair.

You don't take linear algebra unless you know you have a reason to be taking this course. So if you have no reason to be taking this course, I don't think you're going to get much out of it. That said, as a graduate student with programming and statistics experience who avoided taking math courses during my undergraduate career, I found the course very rewarding as it explained the mathematical basis for techniques that I had been using for years. Very happy overall with my experience.

Yes, I would, if Caglar is teaching it! The workload is actually pretty big (and the material is not easy), but I definitely understand a lot of linear algebra now, and Caglar is one of the nicest professors I've had at Yale.
Yes! It was taught very well as a course, and Caglar made it engaging and understandable. If you like math or need to take the class, Math 222 taught by Caglar is a good class.
